captions.text:
Some of our favorite Quick Questions to answer
are the ones where the premise of the question
is flawed.

Like, take this one: Why don’t women have
adam’s apples?

The answer is: I don’t … I can’t answer
that, ‘cause women do have adam’s apples!

Technically, the adam’s apple is known as
the laryngeal prominence, and it’s actually

just a big piece of cartilage that covers
your larynx, or voice box.

Everyone has one, because you need it to protect
your larynx and everything you keep inside

there to make yourself heard, particularly
your vocal folds -- often mistakenly called
vocal cords.

This protection is important enough that there
are actually nine different pieces of cartilage

that work together to protect your larynx.
The one that forms the laryngeal prominence

is the biggest and uppermost piece, called
the thyroid cartilage.

Cartilage is just a kind of stiff, flexible
connective tissue -- it doesn’t have any

nerves or blood vessels in it -- and the prominence
is where two plates of cartilage meet and
fuse together, forming a little peak.

As children, everyone’s laryngeal prominence
is the same size. But when you reach puberty,

your larynx and all of the cartilage around
it grows considerably, giving you your grown-up

voice. But the way in which the cartilage
grows is different depending on your sex.

For biological females, the two plates develop
to form a more obtuse angle, of about 120

degrees. This makes it rest flatter in the
throat.

But in males, the plates form a 90 degree
angle, which makes the prominence even more
prominent.

And because the rapid growth of the larynx
and all its fixins is driven by testosterone,

males’ voice boxes and thyroid cartilage
typically grow more than females’, which

can not only give them deeper voices, it can
also put a bigger lump in their throat.

So an enlarged, angled adam’s apple is considered
a male secondary sex characteristic -- a specific

variation of a feature that everyone actually
has.
Keep the questions coming! We love ‘em!

Thanks for watching this Quick Question, especially
to our Subbable subscribers who get these

videos a little early for subscribing. Thank
you.

If you have a quick question, let us know
on Facebook or on Twitter or in the comments

below, and if you want to keep getting smarter
with us, just go to YouTube.com/scishow and
subscribe!

comments.text:
Sorry if this sounds slightly stupid, or doesnt make sense.

Where are we in time?
We have developed so much in the whole existence of the earth. And this is 
the most developed we have been so far. In the future, how many things will 
have developed and changed.
We are currently living in 2014, which is a long time away from 1 AD, yet 
so close. It has only been the 2000th year, how many more will there be?
We look back at (in no order) the celts, victorians, time of shakespeare 
etc. and feel like those times were many many years ago, but they were only 
somewhere in the 1000s and were in the 2000s. What about 3000s 4000s 5000s 
etc. but how far away, or how close exactly are we to the beginning and end 
of life.
Someone in my class (im in seventh grade) told me that when the sun stops 
using carbon dioxide as fuel, it will start on hydrogen, and i dont 
remember how, but somehow after this, the world will come to an end. He 
said we have aproximately 12000 years left, but i dont know how accurate he 
is.
So think about it, if people will live until the 12000s, we are actually 
quite near to the beginning of live, and they will think of us as old. And 
thinking about how much we have progressed and developed in 2000 years, 
imagine how much it will have changed in the 12000s. How will our lives 
compare.

And what will happen after that.
﻿

comments.text:
There are some other videos that scishow do that deal with this. Here is a 
short answer.
4 billion years ago: big bang theory
2 billion years ago: earth formed
63 million years ago: extintion of the dinosaurs
100,000 years ago: Homo sapians evolved
10,000 years ago: Adam and eve story
5000 years ago: pyrimids and stone henge were built
2000 years ago: roman, greek and phoenetian empires. birth of christ and 
the year we know as 1 AD
1400 years ago: dark ages begin. collapse of the roman empire
500 years ago: beginning of the renaisance and scientific exploration
1945: end of world war 2
1990: end of the cold war
2001: beginning of the 'war on terror'

I think that is what you wanted to know? Guys i know my numbers are 
approximate and may be a little off (or debatable), but hopefully this will 
give you insight into history and science and maybe encourage you to do 
some reading about anything that grabs your interest. I used to love 
history in high school! :)

It's still amazing to me how many people are just unaware that we really 
all start out the same. Almost all the physical things that make us 
different (gender-wise at least) are due to hormones. Essentially, we all 
start out as "female" at least in structure in the womb and as we grow, 
gender features developed.
This is something that should be taught in school.
(Yes I realize this is rather an oversimplification.)﻿

comments.author: Angel Lewis

comments.text:
Yes all women have them. A little anatomy and physiology lesson: 

The laryngeal prominence (commonly referred to as the Adam's apple), a 
feature of the human neck, refers to the lump or protrusion that is formed 
by the angle of the thyroid cartilage surrounding the thyroid cartilage. It 
is larger in adult men, in whom it is usually clearly visible and palpable. 
In women the bump is much less visible and is hardly perceived on the upper 
edge of the Thyroid cartilage.

The meeting point of the two portions of the cartilage generally forms an 
acute angle (of about 90°) in men, while in women, an open arc (of about 
120°).

The Adam's apple, in conjunction with the thyroid cartilage which forms it, 
helps to protect the walls and the frontal part of the larynx, including 
the vocal cords (which are located directly behind it).
comments.author: Angel Lewis
